topic.title: HP Helion OpenStack 2.0: Installing via the GUI

body.section: HP Helion OpenStack 2.0 comes with a UI, the Dayzero Installer, for first-time installation of your cloud. Rather than editing a number of YAML files to input your specific configuration data, the UI presents forms in which you may enter this information. This can simplify the process of manually finding specific fields and can help avoid syntax errors in the YAML files.

In addition, rather than having to run a series of commands to execute the Cobbler and Ansible scripts that initiate the installation of HP Helion OpenStack, the UI application automates much of the installation process.

You can use the UI to inspect the configuration data at any time. Any edits made via the UI are written to the configuration files when you click the Deploy button. If you simultaneously edit the configuration files manually outside the UI, any changes you have made will be overwritten when you click the Deploy button in the GUI.

The YAML configuration files are stored in a local git repository, as explained in Using git for Configuration Management.
When installing via the GUI, you are starting with a model (example cloud configuration) and can and must edit the underlying example to reflect your environment. However, the full range of customizations is not possible via the GUI as some configuration items are not exposed. Below is the list of what can and cannot be changed:

body.section:
Before you begin Before you run the GUI installer to install your cloud, there are a number of things you need to do to prepare.
Prepare your servers
Gather your information
Server names
IP addresses
Server Roles
PXE MAC addresses
PXE IP addresses
PXE interfaces
IPMI/iLO IP address, username, password
Choose your cloud model/example template. Note that the only option for the Cloud model on KVM with VSA is to have 0 or 3 VSA nodes; there is no option to have 0 VSA nodes. Note also that you cannot put the deployer/lifecycle manager on a dedicated node using the GUI installer; it can only run in the control plane using the models exposed here.
Before you use the GUI to install your cloud, you may install the operating system, HP Linux for HP Helion OpenStack, on your nodes (servers) based on your hypervisor, if you prefer. Otherwise the installer will install it for you. The option is available in the GUI. If you deci You must do so by following the appropriate installation instructions.
KVM
ESX For ESX installations, modify ~/helion/hos/ansible/hlm-deploy.yml to uncomment the line containing eon-deploy.yml. You must then comment out the line containing ceph-deploy.yml, vsa-deploy.yml, and cmc-deploy.yml. Then if you need to, follow the instructions in Step 4 here
Before starting the GUI, you will also need to remove executable permission on ~/hlm-ux-implementation/server/ansible/hosts/localhost. Execute the following command to do so: chmod -x ~/hlm-ux-implementation/server/ansible/hosts/localhost This will set the correct permission on the localhost file so that the ready-install-os.yml playbook can run and install the operating system on the nodes.

Running the GUI to install your cloud
Now that the operating system, HP Linux for HP Helion OpenStack, is installed on all your servers (nodes), you will configure and install your cloud using the GUI.
The GUI is found on the deployer node at: http://<Deployer_IP>:79/dayzero
To create a secure tunnel/port forwarding into Apache from the deployer to enable use of the GUI in a browser, SSH tunnel into the deployer with the username/password set up when installing the deployer. Username and password should be what was set in "Set up the Deployer" in the installation instructions. For example: ssh -v -N -L 8080:<Deployer_IP>:79 <Username>@<Deployer_IP>
Then on your local machine, point your web browser to: http://localhost:8080/dayzero As you proceed through the GUI, you need only supply your server names and IP addresses.

In the Assign network groups: External VM network fields, do not add entries for CIDR, Gateway, or IP Range, only VLAN ID. Neutron will assign these.
When the installation is complete, the Ansible log will be displayed on the final page.

section.title: Using the installer securely
section.p: The GUI installer is a web-based application that runs on the deployer/lifecycle manager node and is implemented in nodejs. Currently this application runs behind Apache 2.0 where requests are proxied to the nodejs Express Web Server. The nodejs Express Server runs on port 3000 and Apache runs on port 79.

You should access the installer through Apache and not directly from the Express server. An Example URL looks like this: http://<deployer-host-ip>:79/dayzero. When you finish installing, the Installer will be disabled via Ansible. The GUI installer will also be disabled if you complete a deployment using the CLI.

body.section:
The GUI is used only once: during the initial installation of your cloud.
For VSA you must follow the steps outlined in the VSA Configuration page. After deployment, continue to Verifying Your Installation and Post-Installation Checklist.
To understand a cloud configuration more thoroughly and to learn how to make any changes later, visit these documentation pages:
HP Helion OpenStack 2.0 Input Model
Using Git for Configuration Management
The GUI installer is disabled after deployment finishes - either via the GUI or via the command line. If you want to re-enable the GUI later but are not re-installing from scratch, run these commands: sudo a2ensite dayzero-apache.conf sudo systemctl start dayzero.service
